title: 2 kuttu (buckwheat) recipes you must try today : How to, News - India Today
text:
How to 2 kuttu (buckwheat) recipes you must try today What's a fast without some kuttu pooris to go with your jeera aloo, and kuttu bhallas for a delicious dahi vada? A + A - Buckwheat pooris are an integral part of the Navratri platter, even at Cafe Delhi Heights. Image taken for representational purposes. Photo: Sid Nath, Cafe Delhi Heights 
There's really no joy compared to the kind you get when you bite into a crunchy poori, or dip a spoon into a light dahi vada. And these are culinary experiences you just shouldn't deprive yourself of at any point of time. But what do you do when you're supposed to keep to a proper fast? 
No, you don't deprive yourself. You just get some buckwheat flour or kuttu ka atta, and whip up some special dishes. 
A fasting platter is incomplete without at least one buckwheat or kuttu dish, whether it's the traditional poori and khichdi, or the more recent adaptations such as dahi vada and dosa. You could have a number of other accompaniments with this, from jeera aloo to lauki kheer. But you just have to have that one kuttu dish that is the centre piece of your large and traditional fasting platter. 
A high source of energy and gluten free, buckwheat is almost necessary to stay fit during the period or fasting (and even afterwards). If you don't know yet how to make poori or bhallas with buckwheat flour, don't panic. Just check out these two easy recipes, and you'll be cooking with kuttu like a pro in no time. 
Also read: Navratri diet is one of the healthiest, if you do it the right way 
Buckwheat Dahi Vada You can have your favourite tangy and savoury snack during any fast with this simple dahi vada or bhalla recipe. And, despite the vadas being deep fried, this is a very healthy snack. So feel free to indulge in them even after your fast is over. You shouldn't deprive yourself of dahi vadas, even during Navratri. Image for representational purposes. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/vegrecipesofindia 
Ingredients: 1 cup kuttu atta1/2 cup water1/4 tsp cumin seeds1/2 tsp ginger, chopped10 kichmish or raisins1 cup dahi or yogurt1/4 tsp roasted cumin powder1/4 tsp pepper powder1 tsp saltChopped coriander (garnish)Tamarind chutney (garnish)Green chutney (garnish)Oil, to fry1 bowl water Method: 1. Take the kuttu atta in a large bowl. Add half a cup of water, and whisk thoroughly.2. Add the cumin seeds, chopped ginger, and raisins. Mix well.3. Heat oil in a wok or kadhai, and make small or medium-sized vadas or dumplings with the kuttu batter. Fry them till they turn golden brown, remove from heat, and set aside for a few minutes.4. Take a bowl of water, and mix the salt in it. Put the vadas in the bowl, and let them soak for 20 minutes or an hour. Squeeze the vadas gently right before serving them.5. Whisk the curd thoroughly with a few a spoon full of water. Season it with salt and pepper.6. In a plate, arrange the drained kuttu vada. Drizzle enough yogurt over them, and top with a sprinkling of roasted cumin powder, chopped coriander, tamarind chutney, and green chutney. 
Also read: Have you ever tried a gourmet Navratri meal? Now you can, at these places in Delhi NCR Buckwheat Poori A few of these pooris, and you'll have enough energy to last without any of the spicy, regular dishes that you have to fill your tummy with. Pair these pooris with jeera aloo, or petha, or just halwa. It's sublime any way you have it. You can have kuttu pooris with other Navratri classics, like jeera aloo and petha. Picture courtesy: Pinterest/Manjula's kitchen 
Ingredients: 1 cup buckwheat flour or kuttu atta1/2 cup potato, boiled and mashed1/2 tsp salt1/2 tsp cumin seeds1/8 tsp red pepper1/3 cup water1/4 cup buckwheat flour to roll the poorisOil, to fry 
Method: 1. Mix buckwheat flour, cumin seeds, pepper, and salt in a large bowl. Add the mashed potatoes, and mix well. Add warm water gradually to make a smooth and soft dough. Set aside for five minutes.2. Separate the dough in small or medium-sized balls. Smooth them out by rolling them between your palms. Dunk or dip them in a separate bowl of buckwheat flour to make it easier to roll them out. 3. Roll out the puris in a a thin circle. Sprinkle some more flour if they start sticking to the rolling board.4. Heat oil in a wok or kadhai. Check if the oil is hot enough by dropping a small piece of dough: if it floats then it's ready. Place one poori at a time in the kadhai, press lightly with a slotted spoon, and let them puff up slowly.5. Turn the pooris over to fry evenly on all sides. Take them off the heat once they're cooked through. Serve hot with dishes of your choice. 
You just need to try these two recipes once, and you'll end up making them more often than you know. They're the perfect balance between healthy and deep fried, thanks to the basic qualities of buckwheat flour. This is one grain and flour you should consume more to stay a fit and healthy foodie, during your fast, and after.
